reasoning: The critique targets the paper’s “value as product of many factors” framing, which is an important intuitive support for the “no easy eutopia” conclusion (Section 2.4) but not the only support: the essay also leans heavily on (i) many concrete ways futures can go morally wrong (2.3) and (ii) the more technical argument that many plausible value functions are “fussy” (Section 3). So refuting multiplicativity would weaken, but not collapse, the overall position (moderate centrality). As an objection, it is directionally apt—multiplicativity does build in strong fragility and the piece doesn’t fully justify it as the correct aggregator—but the critique is fairly generic and doesn’t engage the essay’s other routes to fragility (fat-tailed value-efficiency, linear/unbounded arguments, bounded separate-aggregation sensitivity to bads), nor show that plausible alternative aggregators would make mostly-great futures common under the paper’s own setup. Hence only modest strength. It is reasonably relevant to Forethought’s agenda because multiplicative EV decompositions (S×F, product-of-factors) and “narrow target” claims are central to their flourishing/trajectory work; however it does not dig into one of their clearest Tier-3 live disputes or offer a concrete alternative model/implication. Overall, it’s a useful but limited weakening rather than a deep refutation.
title: "The multiplicativity assumption lacks moral justification"
